description: From Middle English rebuken, from Anglo-Norman rebuker (“to beat back, repel”), from re- + Old French *buker, buchier, buschier (“to strike, hack down, chop”), from busche (“wood”), from Vulgar Latin *busca (“wood, grove”), from Frankish *busk (“grove”), from Proto-Germanic *buskaz (“bush”); equivalent to re- +‎ bush.

verbs.description: rebuke (third-person singular simple present rebukes, present participle rebuking, simple past and past participle rebuked)

entries.meaning: (of a person) To criticise harshly; to reprove.
examples: 2011,  Biblica,  Holy Bible: New International Version, Grand Rapids, Mich.: Zondervan, →ISBN, 6::O Lord, do not rebuke me in Your anger or discipline me in Your wrath.
